d:orderedlist.d:listitem:
Let 7+8i=a+ib∴7+8i=a2−b2+2iab
Comparing real and imaginary parts we have,
a2-b2=7 and 2ab=8. Now, we can write following
(a2+b2)2=(a2-b2)2+4a2b2=72+82=113
⇒a2+b2=±113
Now we can rewrite this as 2a2=7±113⇒a=±7±1132
Problem no. 2, 3, 4, and 5 can be solved similarly.

Given complex number can be rewritten as
2a2=7±113⇒a=±7±1132
On simplification ⇒xy+yx-i42
Therefore, square root is ±xy+yx-i4
Problem no. 7, 8, 9 and 10 can be solved similarly.

Given expression can be rewritten as in(i80+i50)=in(i20*4+i12*4+2)=in(1-1)=0.
Problem no. 12, 13, 14 and 15 can be solved similarly.
Given 11-cosθ+2isinθ=1-cosθ-2isinθ(1-cosθ)2+4sin2θ Now all that remains is isolating real and imaginary parts.

Given
(cosx+isinx)(cosy+isiny)(cotu+i)(i+tanv)=(cosxcosy−sinxsiny)+i(sinxcosy+cosxsiny)(cosu+isinu)(sinv+icosv)sinucosv=sinucosv(cos(x+y)+isin(x+y))cos(u+v)+isin(u+v)
Now it is as simple as multiplying this with conjugate of denominator and expanding. However, there is a very neat way of solving this using Eulers formula so let us see that also. Using Euler’s formula we can rewrite the fraction as sinucosveixeiyeiueiπ2-v.

Let z=x+iy then ⇒ z2+|z|=x2-y2+2ixy+x2+y2=0
2xy=0⇒ x=0 or y=0
If x=0 then -y2+y2=0 ⇒y=±1
If y=0 then x2+x2 ⇒x=±1
But when x=±1,x2+x2=2≠0 So our complex number is 0 or ±i
Second methos: z2=-z= a real number.
z2=-z is a real number or is a purely imaginary number. Case I: When z is real. Let z=x then as shown above x=0.
Case II:When z is purely imaginary. Let z=y then as shown above y=±1
Thus, z=0,±i

Let z=x+iy For part z=0⇒x2+y2=0
⇒x2+y2=0⇒x=0 and y=0
Given (x+5i)-(3-iy)=7+8i⇒(x-3)+(5-y)i=7+8i. Equating real and imaginary parts we have x-3=7⇒x=10 and 5-y=8⇒y=13
This is similar to previous problem and is left as an exercise to the reader.

Given that, z=1⇒x2+y2=1. Now we need to evaluate z-1z+1⇒(x-1)+iy(x+1)+iy
Multiplying and dividing by conjugate of denominator we have ((x-1)+iy)(x+1)-iy)(x+1)+iy)(x+1)-iy)⇒(x2+y2-1)+i(xy+y-xy+y)(x+1)2+y2.
Now we know that from given equality real part of previous expression is zero therefore it is purely imaginary.

d:orderedlist.d:listitem: Given, a−ib=x−iy⇒a−ib=x2−y2−i2xy. Equating real and imaginary parts we have, a=x2−y2andb=2xy ∴a+ib=x2−y2+i2xy=x+iy

We will solve this problem by method of negation. Let us say there is a complex number y+iz which is root of this equation. Therefore, this root will satisfy this equation. Hence, A2y+iz−a+B2y+iz−b+...+H2y+iz−h=y+iz+l Multiplying and dividing each term with conjugate of denominator we get A2(y−a−iz)(y−a)2+z2+B2(y−b−iz)(y−b)2+z2+C2(y−c−iz)(y−c)2+z2+...+H2(y−h−iz)(y−h)2+z2=y+iz+l Considering imaginary parts only, we have −iz[A2(y−a)2+z2+B2(y−b)2+z2+C2(y−c)2+z2+...+H2(y−h)2+z2]=iz⇒iz[1+A2(y−a)2+z2+B2(y−b)2+z2+C2(y−c)2+z2+...+H2(y−h)2+z2]=0 since the expression has one within bracket it is greater than 1. ∴iz=0⇒z=0

Since our complex number is unimodular |z|=1. Let, z=cosθ+isinθ Equating it to given equivalent ratio we have cosθ+isinθ=c+ic−i=(c+i)(c+i)(c−i)(c+i)⇒cosθ+isinθ=c2−1+2cic2+1 Equating real and imaginary parts, cosθ=c2−1c2+1⇒c2=cot2θ2⇒c=±cotθ2And sinθ=2cc2+1⇒c=cotθ2,tantheta2 From these two common values of c is cotθ2 where θ≠2nπ [∵z is purely real.] ∴z=c+ic−i

Let us name the given number as z. z=sinx2+cosx2−itanx1+2isinx2⇒z=(sinx2+cosx2−itanx)(1−2isinx2)(1+2isinx2)(1−2isinx2) Since z is real Im(z)=0 hence equating imaginary part of above to zero we get following since denominator is real: −tanx−2sinx2sinx2−2sinx2cosx2=0⇒2sinx2(sinx2+cosx2)+2sinx2cosx2cosx=0⇒sinx2=0⇒x=2nπwheren=0,1,2,3,...or(sinx2+cosx2)cosx+cosx2=0⇒2sin3x2−2cos3x2−sinx2=0⇒tan3x2−tanx2−2=0 Let α be a root which satisfies this equation. Hence, x=2nπ+α,n∈I
Let z=3+2i then z¯=3−2i,|z|=3+4=7 and arg(z)=tan−132.
Given complex number is z=a+ibx−iy=(a+ib)(x+iy)x2+y2=(ax−by)+i(ay+bx)x2+y2⇒r=|z|=(ax−by)2+(ay+bx)2(x2+y2)2⇒arg(z)=θ=tan−1ax−byay+bx
R. H. S. = 1z1+1z2 z1+z2z1z2 ∵|z1|=1 and ∵|z2|=1 ∴|z1z2|=1 Now it is trivial to prove it.
We have, a+ib3=x+iy⇒a+ib=x3−3xy2+i(3x2y−y3) Equating real and imaginary parts a=x3−3xy2and b=3x2y−y3⇒ax=x2−3y2and by=3x2−y2 Adding both ax+by=4(x2−y2).
We have, x+iy=a+ibc+ib⇒(x+iy)2=a+ibc+id⇒|(x+iy)2|=|a+ibc+id|=|a+ib||c+id|⇒(x2+y2)2=a2+b2c2+d2.

We have, 32+cosθ+isinθ=a+ib⇒3(2+cosθ−isinθ)(2+cosθ+isinθ)(2+cosθ−isinθ)=a+ib Taking 3 to denominator and equating real and imaginary parts we have a=2+cosθand b=sinθ⇒a2+b2=4+4cosθ+cos2θ+sin2θ⇒5+4cosθ=8+4cosθ−3=4a−3.
Given, m+in=1−ix1+ix=1−x2−2ix1+x2 Equating real and imaginary parts, we get m=1−x21+x2and n=−2x1+x2∴m2+n2=(1−x2)2(1+x2)2+4x2(1+x2)2=1.
This is similar to problem 40 and hence left as an exercise to reader.
We have, 1+ixa1+ixb1+ixc=A +iB Let L.H.S.=z1&R.H.S.=z2 ∵z1=z2∴z1z1¯=z2z2¯ Now it is trivial to evaluate and prove.

Let z1=x1+iy1 and z2=x2+iy2. Then, we have z1+z2z1−z2=((x1+x2)+i(y1+y2))((x1−x2)+i(y1−y2))((x1−x2)−i(y1−y2))((x1−x2)+i(y1−y2)) Neglecting the denominator ⇒Numerator =x12−x22+y12−y22+i(x1y2−x2y1) Now it is given that |z1|=|z2| Hence result is either 0 or purely imaginary based on the fact if z1 is purely real and z2 is purely imaginary or not.
Let, z=x+iy. Now, we have 1∩z= 1 + 0i∩x + iy ⇒1≤x and 0≤y Let, p=1-z1+z=(1-x+iy)(1+x-iy)(1+x+iy)(1+x-iy)=1-x2-y2-i2y(1+x)2+y2 ∴Re(p)≤0 and ∴Im(p)≤0
From the given equation we can deduce that z=−1|z|+a Since a>0 and |z|>0,z is a negative real number from previous equation.
Given x+iy+α(x−1)2+y2+2i=0

Equating real and imaginary parts y+2=0⇒y=-2 and x+α(x-1)2+y2=0 Substituting value of y in second equation αx2−2x+5=−x⇒(α2−1)x2−2α2x+5α2=0 This is similar to problem no. 47 and is left as an exercise. Reader is implored to study chapter on quadratic equations for this.

Let x be a real root then we have
x2+αx+β=0⇒x2+αx=-β
Taking conjugate we have
-β¯=x2¯+αx¯-β¯=x2+α¯x
[because x ir real]. Subtracting, we get β-β¯=(α¯-α)x. Multiplying first equation with α¯ and second with α and subtracting we get αβ¯-α¯β=(α¯-α)x2

f(z)=m(z-i)+i and f(z)=n(z+i)+1+i where m and n are quotients upon division. Substituting z=i in the first equation and z=−i in the second we get. f(i)=i and f(-i)=1+i.
Let g(z) be the quotient and az+b be the remainder upon division of f(z) by z2+1 Hence, we have
f(z)=g(z)(z2+1)+az+b Substituting z=i and z=-i we have
f(i)=i=ai+b[∵i2+1=0]f(-i)=1+i=-ai+b[∵(-i)2+1=0] Adding 2b=1+2i⇒b=1+2i2
Now a can be calculated and az+b evaluated.

Given, iz3+z2-z+i=0
=iz2(z-i)-1(z-i)
=(iz2-1)(z-i)
Either iz2-1=0⇒z2=-i⇒|z|2=1⇒|z|=1
or z-i=0⇒|z|=1

We know that for two complex numbers z1 and z2 z1+z2|2+|z1-z2|2=2|z1|2+2|z2|2
Let
z1=α+α2-β2
z1=α-α2-β2
|z1|2+|z2|2=|z1|2+|z2|2+2|z1||z2|
=12|z1+z2|2+|z1-z2|2+2|z1z2|
Solving this gives us our desired results.

Given |z1|=|z2|=1∴ a2+b2=1 and c2+d2=1
Also given that
Re(z1z2¯)=0⇒ac+bd=0
ad=-cd=p
∵a2+b2=1⇒p2(c2+d2)=1
Now it is trivial to prove the orioginal equalities.
